messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> On Oct 22, 2007 12:18 PM, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...
> <mailto:jbrains762%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> > It's getting older, but the suggestions in _JUnit Recipes_ have yet to
> > be replaced with better advice, at least in print.
>
> But they have :-)
>
> http://www.amazon.com/Next-Generation-Java-Testing-Advanced/dp/0321503104/ref=sr_1_1/104-2778163-0055136?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1193082632&sr=8-1
> <http://www.amazon.com/Next-Generation-Java-Testing-Advanced/dp/0321503104/ref=sr_1_1/104-2778163-0055136?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1193082632&sr=8-1>
>
> We cover EB3, mocks, dependency injections and a host of cutting edge
> frameworks, such as Guice.
>
> More seriously: I'm not saying our advice is better than the one
> found in JB's excellent book, but maybe just more up to date.

Good to know. I would hate to point people to old advice. The basics
never change: narrow dependencies and separate framework extension
points from plain Java code. Still, what should I do if I have to test
this in the container? What compromises can I get away with? How does
EJB 3 change the tradeoffs? I don't know these things. I'm glad someone
has written about it. Now I know where to refer people.
